selected_quotes: Check out the #boxing study getting the buzz -- head guards in boxing, good or bad?
Use of Head Guards in AIBA Boxing Tournaments. A Cross-Sectional Observational Study #headinjury #boxing #headgear
Does removing head guards reduce the risk of acute brain injury in amateur boxing.
Use of head gear in #boxing - cross-sectional observational study #OriginalResearch #OnLineFirst

citation.abstract:
This study looks at the changes in injuries after the implementation of a new rule by the International Boxing Association (AIBA) to remove head guards from its competitions.
A cross-sectional observational study performed prospectively. This brief report examines the removal of head guards in 2 different ways. The first was to examine the stoppages due to blows to the head by comparing World Series Boxing (WSB), without head guards, to other AIBA competitions with head guards. Secondly, we examined the last 3 world championships: 2009 and 2011 (with head guards) and 2013 (without head guards).
World Series Boxing and AIBA world championship boxing.
Boxers from WSB and AIBA world championships.
The information was recorded by ringside medical physicians.
Stoppages per 10 000 rounds; stoppages per 1000 hours.
Both studies show that the number of stoppages due to head blows was significantly decreased without head guards. The studies also showed that there was a notable increase in cuts.
Removing head guards may reduce the already small risk of acute brain injury in amateur boxing.
citation.title: Use of Head Guards in AIBA Boxing Tournaments—A Cross-Sectional Observational Study

news.title: Why Olympic Boxers Aren’t Wearing Headgear Anymore
news.summary: Something is missing from Olympics boxing this year. Did you notice? It’s lot easier to see the faces of male boxers—taunting, grimacing, or smiling in all their Olympian glory.

news.title: Pros, cons of boxing headgear remain matter of debate
news.summary: Boxing Canada, the International Boxing Association and the International Olympic Committee have all stated that removing padded headgear reduces the risk of concussions for male boxers.

news.title: El boxeo olímpico sin casco enciende el debate médico
news.summary: El pasado 2 de marzo, el Comité Olímpico Internacional (COI) anunciaba la eliminación del casco en el boxeo para los Juegos de Río 2016 en categoría masculina.
